Description: [JOINT] SUMMARY:  On June 14, 2018, Scott Blaising, regulatory counsel for the City of Lancaster (Lancaster), Marin Clean Energy (MCE), Peninsula Clean Energy Authority (PCE), and Sonoma Clean Power Authority (SCP) (collectively, CCA Parties), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Also present was Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst for PCE; and Jan Pepper, Chief Executive Officer, and Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst, for PCE, Nathaniel Malcolm, counsel for MCE, and David Peffer, regulatory counsel for the Lancaster, participated in the meeting via teleconference. The CCA Parties’ representatives discussed matters related to Commissioner Guzman Aceves’ Alternate Revised Proposed Decision (Revised APD). The CCA Parties representatives stated their support for the programs established by Revised APD, but registered their concern that the Revised APD’s discussion of the Community Solar Green Tariff program does not sufficiently address the role and eligibility of Community Choice Aggregation (CCA) programs. The CCA Parties stated that CCA programs should qualify for funding by administering their own Community Solar Green Tariff programs. The CCA Parties pointed to Demand Response as a helpful analog for how CCA programs could participate in Community Solar Green Tariff programs. The CCA Parties asked that the Revised APD be clarified to invite CCA programs to bring forth Community Solar Green Tariff proposals on an equal footing with the investor-owned utilities (IOUs). The CCA Parties suggested that a workshop might be helpful to develop the expected framework for content in the advice letters. Regarding the Disadvantaged Communities Green Tariff program, the CCA Parties noted that in order to implement a program that is equivalent to the IOUs’ programs CCA customers must be able to offer a discount of 20% off a participating customer’s total bill, which includes both the CCA-produced generation charge and the IOU-produced delivery charge.

Description: SUMMARY:  On April 5, 2018, Shana Lazerow and Amee Raval, on behalf of California Environmental Justice Alliance (CEJA), and Subin DeVar, on behalf of Sustainable Economies Law Center (SELC), had a telephone conversation with Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and met with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and Shanon O’Rourke, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Ms. Lazerow expressed the parties’ support for the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD). Ms. Lazerow explained that community solar is the most similar to standard Net Energy Metering (NEM). Ms. Raval then explained that, while the parties also support Green Tariff and SASH alternatives, the Green Tariff as designed in the APD is not adequate to meet requirements as an alternative to NEM. Mr. DeVar then explained that Community Solar is legal – the legality argument, raised for the first time in a reply comment, is not well-founded in law. Ms. Lazerow explained that communities are already asking for, and contemplating, Community Solar projects that would qualify under the APD.

SUMMARY:  On April 5, 2018, Pradeep Gupta, South San Francisco Councilmember and Member of Peninsula Clean Energy’s Board of Directors and Joseph F. Wiedman, Director of Legislative and Regulatory Affairs, Peninsula Clean Energy Authority (PCE), attended an ex parte meeting with Nidhi Thakar, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. PCE discussed its support for the Alternate Decision and the changes it believes are necessary to support Community Choice Aggregators (CCAs) adopting disadvantaged communities (DAC)-Green Tariffs and/or community solar programs. With respect to the DAC-Green Tariff program, Mr. Wiedman pointed out that CCAs cannot access the funds identified in the Alternate Decision to support such programs. With respect to the Community Solar program, Mr. Wiedman recommended that CCAs be permitted to develop community solar programs aimed at serving their DACs regardless of whether those communities fall into the top 5% of communities per CalEnviroScreen. Mr. Wiedman stated PCE’s support for allowing a community solar facility located in one DAC to be permitted to serve customers within any DAC in a county, and the need for flexibility in timing for identifying benefiting accounts. Mr. Wiedman expressed PCE’s support for workforce development and training requirements. Mr. Gupta noted PCE’s desire to provide opportunities for residents of DACs to access renewable energy resources located in their communities.

SUMMARY:  On April 5, 2018, Dan Buch, Supervisor, the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in San Francisco. Also present were Elizabeth Fox, Public Utilities Regulatory Analyst, and Christa Salo, Staff Attorney, for the ORA. ORA representatives discussed Proposed Decision Adopting Alternatives to Promote Solar Distributed Generation in Disadvantaged Communities (PD) and Alternate PD Adopting Alternatives to Promote Solar Distributed Generation. ORA expressed its support for the DAC-Green Tariff program as the best mechanism to provide the benefits of a solar program to low-income customers in disadvantaged communities. ORA noted that the Disadvantaged Communities-Green Tariff (DAC-Green Tariff) program would be less expensive compared to the Community Solar program proposed in the APD and more efficient since the benefits of the program are narrowly tailored to low-income customers. ORA also stated that the DAC-Green Tariff program would be easy to sign up for making it likely to have a robust level of customer participation. ORA also discussed other alternatives to adopting the Community Solar program proposed in the APD.

SUMMARY:  On April 2, 2018, Dan Buch, Supervisor, the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Maria Sotero, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. SUMMARY:  On March 14, 2018, Sidney Dietz, Director, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Shannon O’Rourke, advisor to Cmmr. SUMMARY:  [LATE FILED.] On December 9, 2018, Stan Greschner, Vice-President of Government Relations and Market Development of GRID Alternatives (GRID), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. GRID personnel shared their objectives for alternatives to the net energy metering (NEM) successor tariff for disadvantaged communities (DACs) being considered in this proceeding, including developing a suite of programs serving various housing arrangements, and implementing programs that will be scalable, have a high likelihood of success, and build upon ratepayer investments to the extent possible. SUMMARY:  On November 7, 2017, Sidney Dietz, Director, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with with Maria Sotero, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Also present was Patrick Hennigan, Senior Analyst, Strategic Analytics, PG&E. Mr. Dietz stated that the strength of PG&E’s proposal, Solar CARE Plus, is that it is targeted to low-income customers, and is designed to be easy for participants compared to more project-based proposals. Mr. Hennigan described PG&E’s proposal, and noted that it is aimed entirely at low income and more of its costs go to benefits for low-income customers, unlike DAC VNEM, which would, as a net effect, put more costs onto CARE customers than it would relieve. Mr. Hennigan further stated that the Solar Care Plus projects can be directed to particular communities that have high participation and so will include the benefits within the community. Mr. Dietz stated that this low-income approach is a better approach, since it alleviates inequity more for every dollar money spent on the program, and can be scaled by the commission to appropriate levels.

SUMMARY:  On June 28th through 30th, 2017, Cyndee Fang, Manager of Customer Pricing for San Diego Gas and Electric Company gave presentations at the Center for Research in Regulated Industries: Advanced Workshop in Regulation and Competition – 30th Annual Western Conference held in Monterey, California.  Scott Murtishaw, advisor to President Picker, was an attendee to the conference and has access to the presentations.  Fang presented the following presentation by Ken Schiermeyer & Will Matsuoka, Forecasting Long-Term Hourly Loads, and a presentation, Solar Adoption & Customer Consumption in the Residential Sector.  Fang stated that Solar Adoption and Customer Consumption presentations showed that upon further examination of the impacts to customers’ load before and after solar continues to indicate that solar adoption is unlikely to result in a reduction in the costs to serve residential solar customers.  Fang noted that while net consumption decreased one year after solar installation, over 43% increased consumption one year after installation, and on average, customers with decreased consumption in Year 1 increased consumption in Year 2, resulting in overall consumption of solar customers increasing two years after installation.  Fang explained that energy usage is not the key indicator to cost of service.  Fang noted that residential customers with solar continue to have peak levels that are over 70% higher than those without solar.  Fang indicated that average size of solar installed has increased by 51% over a 10-year period, while net consumption has increased from '250 kWh per month in 2015 to '280 kWh per month in 2016.  Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

Filed By: Everyday Communications Corp. dba Everyday Energy
Description: SUMMARY:  On May 3, 2017, Scott Sarem; Co-Founder and CEO of Everyday Energy, met with Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Martha Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco.  Also present were Kyra Bush Sarem, Co-Founder and General Counsel of Everyday Energy; Dawn Anaiscourt, Director, CPUC Regulatory Affairs, Southern California Edison Company; Sidney Dietz, Director, Regulatory Relations, and Patrick Hennigan, Senior Strategic Analyst, for Pacific Gas and Electric; Sylvia Martinez, Senior Project Manager, Community Housing Works; G Andrew Blauvelt, Coordinator, the MASH Coalition; Brad Heaver, Policy Director, California Solar Energy Industries Association (CALSEIA), and Tony Brunello from California Strategies.  The purpose of the meeting was to demonstrate that the meeting participants, who collectively have the most extensive experience in delivering solar PV to multifamily affordable housing in the state of California and have been the main participants in the Multifamily Affordable Solar Housing Program (MASH), hereinafter referred to as “the Experienced Parties” – expressed their collective agreement that the legislative intent of AB 693 is to utilize the current MASH Program infrastructure to implement AB 693, and that there is a statutory mandate for the Multifamily Affordable Housing Solar Roofs Program (MASHR) be implemented by June 30, 2017.  The Experienced Parties also discussed their concern that creating a complicated administration regime for the MAHSR Program will drive up the soft costs of providing solar and result in higher solar prices.  The Experienced Parties agree that the Commission should not fund batteries with MAHSR Program funds.  Representatives of Everyday Energy, the MASH Coalition, and CALSEIA suggested that there should be an exemption from mandatory Time of Use rates for residents of multifamily affordable housing served through virtual net metering.

JOINT;  SUMMARY:  On April 5, 2016, Brad Heavner, Policy Director, California Solar Energy Industries Association (CALSEIA), met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Also present were Sara Kamins of the Energy Division; Stephen Rogers, Commercial Solar Consultant of the Solar Company; and Dan Halperin, Director, Distributed Generation, David Gabbard, Director, Electric Generation Interconnection, and Sidney Dietz, Director, Regulatory Relations, for Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E). Halperin described that the queue of projects that would be eligible for NEM 1, under the joint CALSEIA/SEIA/PG&E proposal for new eligibility criteria, will soon be large enough to fill up the NEM 1 cap. Halperin presented a revised version of the NEM Program Limit Report.  Dietz stated that if the cap were filled in this way, it would disadvantage a group of customers who had planned on the current eligibility rules being in place until the cap was hit. Gabbard described that because the change in eligibility would be happening late, there would be a potential gap between when NEM 1 is filled and when NEM 2 is available.  CALSEIA and PG&E representatives discussed potential for an interim tariff that could also be delayed if it is protested. Gabbard further stated that even if the decision were issued quickly, the changes in tariffs and system changes would make the proposal queue even longer if developers of solar systems for residential customers submit Customer Authorizations for projects that have been contracted but not built. Heavner described that PG&E reports its queue differently than Southern California Edison, and that PG&E has recently disclosed that there are more than 300 MW of projects under development that were not previously reported. Gabbard explained that PG&E’s NEM Program Limit Report was consistent with guidelines provided by the CPUC.   Heavner further stated that many large commercial customers have signed solar contracts with expectations of interconnecting under NEM 1, with protection from unanticipated delays through use of a reservation system. Rogers explained that delays in the interconnection study process often lead to delays in project completion. Heavner and Gabbard described a wide range of possible remedies, and stated that none would satisfy the expectations of all types of customers.  Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

Description: [JOINT] SUMMARY:  On January 13, 2016, Joseph Wiedman, counsel for The Alliance for Solar Choice (TASC), met with Nick Chaset, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, Rachel Peterson, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and Ehern Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in three separate meetings in San Francisco.  At the meeting with Peterson also present was Sean Simon, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph. Lyndon Rive, Chief Executive Officer of SolarCity Corp.; Blair Swezey, California Policy Director for Sunpower, Inc.; Walker Wright, Director of Public Policy for Sunrun, Inc.; and Brandon Smithwood, Manager of California State Affairs for the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA), participated in all three meetings. Sanjay Ranchod, Vice President of Policy & Electricity Markets and Regulatory Counsel for SolarCity Corp., participated in the meetings with Rachel Peterson and with Ehern Seybert.  Brad Heavner, Policy Director for the California Solar Energy Industries Association (CALSEIA) participated in the meeting with Rachel Peterson.  Jeanine Cotter, CEO of Luminalt, Inc., participated in the meeting with Ehern Seybert. During these meetings, parties’ (collectively, Joint Solar Parties or JSP) representatives discussed concerns with the investor-owned utilities’ untimely proposal for a net feed-in tariff (net FiT). JSP explained that in addition to consideration of the utilities’ untimely proposal for a net FiT being barred by Commission rules of practice, a FiT would devastate sustained growth in customer-sited distributed generation because FiTs may not be financeable, result in income tax consequences for customers, and jeopardize eligibility for the federal investment tax credit. JSP noted that FiTs have been unsuccessful in supporting sustained growth of customer-sited distributed generation (DG). JSP expressed support for the Proposed Decision’s (PD) determination that time-of-use rates should be a central part of the successor tariff. JSP discussed the importance of the PD’s determination to provide 20 year grandfathering of the successor tariff.  Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On December 18, 2015, Dan Halperin, Director, Distributed Generation, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present were Aaron Johnson, Vice President, Customer Energy Solutions, and Erik Jacobson, Director, Regulatory Relations, for PG&E.  Halperin expressed PG&E's disappointment and opposition to the Net Energy Metering (NEM) proposed decision which does not meaningfully reduce the cost-shift in the current NEM program. Halperin stated that the proposed decision will lock in $2.5-$5.0 billion of annual cost-shifting by 2020. Johnson, Halperin and Jacobson said that the decision by Congress to extend the Investment Tax Credit (ITC) eliminates market uncertainty and will further ensure robust growth of rooftop solar. PG&E representatives said the Commission should reconsider the proposed decision in light of the ITC extension.  PG&E representatives urged the Commission to adopt a successor tariff that significantly reduces the size of this cost-shift and also results in vigorous growth of rooftop solar. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On December 21, 2015, Brad Heavner, Policy Director of the California Solar Energy Industries Association, met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Also present were: Sanjay Ranchod, Vice President of Policy and Electricity Markets for SolarCity; Walker Wright, Director of Public Policy for SunRun; and Brandon Smithwood, Manager of California State Affairs, and Tom Beach, consultant, for Solar Energy Industries Association.  Solar representatives discussed the proposed decision (PD).  Solar representatives expressed that starting mandatory time of use rates at the beginning of the successor tariff could create major customer backlash, that mandating time of use rates for net metered customers who installed solar under tiered rates would be unfair, that the list of non-bypassable charges assessed on exported power should be more limited than the list in the PD, that the new non-bypassable charges should be calculated as a fee rather than embedded in rates, and that greater emphasis should be placed on the total recourse cost test.

Peterman, Sean Simon, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in three separate meetings in San Francisco. SUMMARY:  On December 3, 2015, Steve Malnight, Senior Vice President, Regulatory Affairs, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Nick Chaset, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Also present were Dan Halperin, Director, Distributed Generation, and Erik Jacobson, Director, Regulatory Relations, for PG&E. Malnight stated that PG&E’s approach to NEM reform keys off the objectives of AB 327 and ensuring there is sustainable growth of rooftop solar. Malnight described three key principles for NEM reform. Malnight challenged the assertion of solar parties that NEM reform will derail the solar industry and there is no room to lower PPA prices. Malnight also described PG&E’s concern over the large subsidy of about $2,000 per participant if the existing approach to NEM continues. Halperin explained why PG&E will continue to see rapid growth of distributed generation adoption under PG&E’s proposal. Malnight described the unreasonable avoided cost estimates advocated by the solar parties and challenged their RPS premium assumption. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

[Pursuant to D.14-11-041] SUMMARY: On November 13, 2015, Aaron Johnson, Vice President, Customer Energy Solutions, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), initiated the communication with Edward Randolph, Director of the Energy Division. Also present were: Sarah Kamins, Supervisor, Customer Generation Programs, Energy Division; Sidney Dietz, Director, Regulatory Relations, PG&E; Dan Skopec, Vice President of Regulatory Affairs, and Caroline Winn, Chief Energy Delivery Officer, for San Diego Gas & Electric; Brad Heavner, Policy Director, California Solar Energy Industries Association, and Brandon Smithwood, California State Affairs Manager, Solar Energy Industries Association. Johnson stated that PG&E supports the solar-rooftop industry's efforts to provide certainty about whether a customer will be on the original or successor Net Energy Metering (NEM) tariff and about the treatment of customers during a possible 'gap' identified between PG&E hitting the NEM cap and the possibly-delayed NEM successor decision. Johnson further stated that the a reservation system could solve the uncertainty problem, but that it would cause the automated interconnection process, which takes from one to three days, to be replaced by a manual interconnection process, which would likely take thirty to forty five days.   Johnson stated that PG&E could support an interim 'gap' tariff that would mitigate uncertainty for customers who sign up after the cap. Dietz stated that either solution would require a revised NEM tariff and, if protested, could take as long or longer than the NEM successor decision and its tariff revision.

SUMMARY: On November 12, 2015, Brad Heavner, Policy Director for the California Solar Energy Industries Association (CALSEIA), met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Also present were Don Osborn, President of Spectrum Solar, and Jeanine Cotter, President, for Luminalt Solar.  CALSEIA representatives expressed that continuation of virtual net metering is essential to maintaining the opportunity for apartment buildings to install solar power, and that reducing export compensation would effectively make both the low income and market rate virtual net metering tariffs unusable. CALSEIA explained its proposal that the single service delivery point limitation in the current market rate VNEM tariff be eliminated to conform with the participation rules in the current low income VNEM tariff. CALSEIA representatives also stressed the need to maintain diversity in the solar industry.

Description: [Joint] SUMMARY:  On May 13, 2015, R. Thomas Beach, outside consultant for the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA), met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Also present were Marc Kolb, Eliah Gilfenbaum, and Andy Schwartz of The Alliance for Solar Choice (TASC), and Mark Fulmer, outside consultant for TASC.  The representatives of SEIA and TASC discussed their concerns with the draft version of the Public Tool, focusing on the adoption models for solar and storage that are included in the Tool. They also discussed the structure of the cost of service model and the importance of other options to curtailment for dealing with possible renewable over-generation in a 50% RPS scenario. The SEIA and TASC representatives recommended that Energy Division and E3 modify these elements of the Tool, as they are difficult for users to know how to change.
